div.p: It is shown that, for a harmonic oscillator in the ground state, Bohmian mechanics and quantum mechanics predict values of opposite sign for certain time correlations.

The discrepancy can be explained by the fact that Bohmian mechanics has no natural way to accomodate the Heisenberg picture, since the local expectation values that define the beables of the theory depend on the Heisenberg time being used to define the operators.
Relations to measurement are discussed, too, and shown to leave no loophole for claiming that Bohmian mechanics reproduces all predictions of quantum mechanics exactly.
Keywords: Bohmian mechanics, quantum mechanics, pilot wave, causal interpretation, local expectation value, harmonic oscillator, time correlations

br.p: 1998Â Â PACS Classification: 03.65.Bz
E-print Archive No.: quant-ph/0001011

div.p: Since its inception by Bohm [6] and its popularization by Bell [3], the pilot wave theory, or causal interpretation of quantum mechanics â€“ now often called Bohmian mechanics â€“ has been regarded by a number of people as a in some respects bizarre but otherwise viable ontology for quantum mechanics. Books and proceedings appeared that discuss the features of the theory in detail, cf. Holland [20], Bohm & Hiley [7], Cushing et al. [9], good introductory surveys are available, cf. Berndl et al. [4], DÃ¼rr et al. [14], and accounts for the lay reader exist, cf. Albert [1], Goldstein [18].

On the other hand, Bohmian mechanics has remained a minority view, since, from its beginnings, it had been critically viewed by most of the influential quantum physicists. The main early arguments against it are stated in Holland [20, Sections 1.5.3 and 6.5.3]; they are usually argued away by some mathematical analysis accompanied by statements such as â€œclassical prejudiceâ€ (Bell [3, Chapter 14]),â€œto our knowledge no serious technical objections have ever been raised againstâ€ it (Holland [20, Section 1.5.3]), or â€œBohmian mechanics accounts for all of the phenomena governed by nonrelativistic quantum mechanicsâ€ (DÃ¼rr et al. [14]). The arguments on both sides usually rest on oneâ€™s unwillingness or readiness to accept counterintuitive consequences of the Bohmian picture, since none of the phenomena in question are observable.

More recent counterintuitive implications of Bohmian mechanics (Englert et al. [15], Griffiths [19]) met with similar responses (DÃ¼rr et al. [13], Dewdney et al. [11]). In particular, DÃ¼rr et al. write, â€œan open-minded advocate of quantum orthodoxy would presumably have preferred the clearer and stronger claim that BM is incompatible with the predictions of quantum theory, so that, despite its virtues, it would not in fact provide an explanation of quantum phenomena. The authors are, however, aware that such a strong claim would be false.â€

The purpose of this paper is to demonstrate â€“ independent of the arguments in [15, 19, 20] â€“ that such a strong claim is valid indeed. Specifically, Bohmian mechanics contradicts the predictions of quantum mechanics at the level of time correlations. Since time correlations can be observed experimentally via linear response theory (see, e.g., Reichl [27, Chapter 15.H]), Bohmian mechanics and quantum mechanics cannot be both valid.

Concerning discrepancies between Bohmian mechanics and quantum mechanics involving multiple times, see also Redington et al. [26] for Bohmian hydrogen atoms, and Ghose [17] for histories of indistinguishable particles.

There are similar problems with multiple times in Nelsonâ€™s [25] stochastic quantum mechanics; however, there they can be overcome by a specific procedure for state reduction under measurement, see Blanchard et al. [5]. Bohmian mechanics does not seem to have such an option to rescue their case since in the orthodox Bohmian interpretation state reduction is a purely dynamical phenomenon.

br.p: Acknowledgments. Iâ€™d like to thank Philippe Blanchard, Sheldon Goldstein, Arkadiusz Jadzcyk and Jack Sarfatti for their comments on an earlier version of this paper.

div.p: Quantum mechanics. A one-dimensional quantum particle without spin in an external potential Vâ¢(q)ğ‘‰ğ‘italic-V OPEN:( italic-q CLOSE:)V(q) is described by the Hamiltonian

div.p: (see, e.g., Messiah [24, (2.20)]), where the position operator qğ‘italic-qq and the momentum operator pğ‘italic-pp satisfy the canonical commutation relations

semantics.annotation: OPEN:[ italic-q PUNCT:, italic-p CLOSE:] RELOP:equals italic-i italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: [24, (5.53)]. In the SchrÃ¶dinger picture, observables are associated with Hermitian operators Ağ´italic-AA. The dynamics of a quantity Ağ´italic-AA is given in the Heisenberg picture by one-parameter families of operators Aâ¢(t)ğ´ğ‘¡italic-A OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)A(t) satisfying

div.p: [24, (8.40)]; the identification with the SchrÃ¶dinger picture is obtained by specifying the initial condition Aâ¢(0)=Ağ´0ğ´italic-A OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-AA(0)=A at some reference time t=0ğ‘¡0italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:0t=0.

In the position representation, pure ensemble states are given by wave functions Ïˆ0â¢(x)subscriptğœ“0ğ‘¥italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\psi_{0}(x) satisfying âˆ«|Ïˆ0â¢(x)|2â¢ğ‘‘x=1superscriptsubscriptğœ“0ğ‘¥2differential-dğ‘¥1INTOP:integral VERTBAR:| italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\int|\psi_{0}(x)|^{2}dx=1, on which qğ‘italic-qq acts as multiplication by xğ‘¥italic-xx and pğ‘italic-pp acts as the differential operator h-iâ¢âˆ‡superscriptâ„ğ‘–âˆ‡FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-i ARG:end OPERATOR:nabla\frac{h\hskip-5.690551pt^{-}}{i}\nabla. The expectation of a Heisenberg operator family Aâ¢(t)ğ´ğ‘¡italic-A OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)A(t) in a pure ensemble is defined by

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle italic-A OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals INTOP:integral italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-A OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) italic-d italic-x
\langle A(t)\rangle_{Q}=\int\psi_{0}^{*}(x)(A(t)\psi_{0})(x)dx

div.p: [24, (4.22)]. If one defines a time-dependent wave function Ïˆâ¢(x,t)ğœ“ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)\psi(x,t) as the solution of the initial-value problem

semantics.annotation: italic-i italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-t ARG:end italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-H italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)
ih\hskip-5.690551pt^{-}\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\psi(x,t)=H\psi(x,t),~{}~{}~% {}\psi(x,0)=\psi_{0}(x)

div.p: [24, (2.29)], one can rewrite the expectation in the equivalent SchrÃ¶dinger picture as

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle italic-A OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals INTOP:integral italic-psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-A italic-psi CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) italic-d italic-x
\langle A(t)\rangle_{Q}=\int\psi^{*}(x,t)(A\psi)(x,t)dx

div.p: [24, (4.22)]. In particular, the expectation of a function of position is

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle italic-f OPEN:( italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals INTOP:integral italic-f OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x
\langle f(q(t))\rangle_{Q}=\int f(x)|\psi(x,t)|^{2}dx
italic-P OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals VERTBAR:| italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: [24, (4.2)] behaves as a probability density. For Hamiltonians of the form (1), the probability density satisfies an equation of continuity,

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-t ARG:end italic-P ADDOP:plus BIGOP:div italic-J RELOP:equals NUMBER:0
\frac{\partial}{\partial t}P+\mathop{\rm div}J=0

div.p: [24, (4.11)], with the probability current

semantics.annotation: italic-J OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals BIGOP:Re italic-psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-i italic-m ARG:end OPERATOR:nabla italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)
J(x,t)=\mathop{\rm Re}\psi^{*}(x,t)\frac{h\hskip-5.690551pt^{-}}{im}\nabla\psi% (x,t)

div.p: [24, (4.9)]. Thus an ensemble behaves like a flow of noninteracting particles.

br.p: Bohmian mechanics. Bohmian mechanics tries to give reality to this picture of an ensemble as a flow of particles with classical-like properties.

div.p: Following Holland [20, Section 3.1], ensembles are interpreted in Bohmian mechanics as classical ensembles of particles characterized by a solution Ïˆâ¢(x,t)ğœ“ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)\psi(x,t) of SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s wave equation (5) and a trajectory xâ¢(t)ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-x OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)x(t) obtained by solving the initial value problem

semantics.annotation: OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-x ARG:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-m ARG:end OPERATOR:nabla italic-S OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x RELOP:equals italic-x OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,
\dot{x}(t)=\frac{1}{m}\nabla S(x,t)\Big{|}_{x=x(t)},

div.p: where the phase Sâ¢(x,t)ğ‘†ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-S OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)S(x,t) of Ïˆğœ“italic-psi\psi is defined by

semantics.annotation: italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-S OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| PERIOD:.
\psi(x,t)=e^{iS(x,t)/h\hskip-5.690551pt^{-}}|\psi(x,t)|.

div.p: The probability that a particle in the ensemble lies between the points xğ‘¥italic-xx and x+dâ¢xğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¥italic-x ADDOP:plus italic-d italic-xx+dx at time tğ‘¡italic-tt is given by |Ïˆâ¢(x,t)|2â¢dâ¢xsuperscriptğœ“ğ‘¥ğ‘¡2ğ‘‘ğ‘¥VERTBAR:| italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x|\psi(x,t)|^{2}dx. (Holland discusses the 3-dimensional case and hence has a volume element in place of dâ¢xğ‘‘ğ‘¥italic-d italic-xdx. It would be trivial to rewrite the present discussion in three dimensions without changing the conclusion. Similarly, as in many expositions of Bohmian mechanics, spin is ignored, but incorporating it would not change anything essential.)

To indicate the flow of individual particles in an ensemble described by a fixed solution Ïˆâ¢(x,t)ğœ“ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)\psi(x,t) of the SchrÃ¶dinger equation, we refine the notation and write xÎ¾â¢(t)subscriptğ‘¥ğœ‰ğ‘¡italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)x_{\xi}(t) for the position of a particle that is in position Î¾ğœ‰italic-xi\xi at time t=0ğ‘¡0italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:0t=0, so that xÎ¾â¢(0)=Î¾subscriptğ‘¥ğœ‰0ğœ‰italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-xix_{\xi}(0)=\xi. The associated probability measure is then dâ¢Î¼â¢(Î¾)=|Ïˆ0â¢(Î¾)|2â¢dâ¢Î¾ğ‘‘ğœ‡ğœ‰superscriptsubscriptğœ“0ğœ‰2ğ‘‘ğœ‰italic-d italic-mu OPEN:( italic-xi CLOSE:) RELOP:equals VERTBAR:| italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-xi CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-xid\mu(\xi)=|\psi_{0}(\xi)|^{2}d\xi. Ensemble expectations of some real property AÎ¾subscriptğ´ğœ‰italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{\xi} that a particle â€“ characterized by its wave function Ïˆ0subscriptğœ“0italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\psi_{0} (asumed fixed) and its position Î¾ğœ‰italic-xi\xi at time t=0ğ‘¡0italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:0t=0 â€“ has are therefore given by averaging the values of Ağ´italic-AA over the ensemble,

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle italic-A CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals INTOP:integral italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-xi CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-xi PERIOD:.
\langle A\rangle_{B}=\int A_{\xi}|\psi_{0}(\xi)|^{2}d\xi.

div.p: Since

semantics.annotation: italic-J OPEN:( italic-x OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-P OPEN:( italic-x OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-x ARG:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)
J(x(t),t)=P(x(t),t)\dot{x}(t)

div.p: [20, (3.2.29)], the continuity equation (10) implies that expectations of functions Aâ¢(xâ¢(t),t)ğ´ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¡italic-A OPEN:( italic-x OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)A(x(t),t) are invariant under a shift of the reference time t=0ğ‘¡0italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:0t=0. (Note that other authors use the equation

semantics.annotation: OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-x ARG:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-J OPEN:( italic-x OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-P OPEN:( italic-x OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)
\dot{x}(t)=J(x(t),t)/P(x(t),t)

div.p: in place of (11) to define the trajectories; because of (14), this is indeed equivalent and has the advantage of being directly motivated by time shift invariance.)

br.p: Local expectation values. To calculate expectation values of quantum mechanical operators, Holland [20, (3.5.4)] defines the local expectation value of a Hermitian operator Ağ´italic-AA in the SchrÃ¶dinger picture as the real number

semantics.annotation: italic-A OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals BIGOP:Re FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPEN:( italic-A italic-psi CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end PERIOD:.
A(x,t)=\mathop{\rm Re}\frac{(A\psi)(x,t)}{\psi(x,t)}.

br.p: The local expectation values evaluated along a trajectory,

semantics.annotation: italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-A OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

br.p: are considered to be the real properties of a particle. Indeed, Holland mentions in [20, Section 3.7.2] that the local expectation value â€œmight, following the common parlance, be termed the â€˜hidden variableâ€™ associated with the corresponding physical variableâ€. With this definition of real properties, Bohmian mechanics achieves agreement with simple quantum mechanical predictions since, as is easily checked,

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle italic-A CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:langle italic-A CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
\langle A\rangle_{B}=\langle A\rangle_{Q}

br.p: (Holland [20, (3.8.8/9)]). To appreciate what the local expectation values are in specific cases, Holland calculates explicitly the case of position, momentum, total energy, and total orbital angular momentum. In particular, the particle positions (local expectation values of A=qğ´ğ‘italic-A RELOP:equals italic-qA=q) and particle momenta (local expectation values of A=pğ´ğ‘italic-A RELOP:equals italic-pA=p) at arbitrary times tğ‘¡italic-tt are

semantics.annotation: italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPERATOR:nabla italic-S OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)

br.p: [20, (3.2.18)]. More generally, if A=fâ¢(q)ğ´ğ‘“ğ‘italic-A RELOP:equals italic-f OPEN:( italic-q CLOSE:)A=f(q) then Aâ¢(x,t)=fâ¢(x)ğ´ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘“ğ‘¥italic-A OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-f OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)A(x,t)=f(x); thus functions of position at a fixed time behave classically. But for other operators, this is not the case; e.g., while pÎ¾â¢(t)=mâ¢xË™Î¾â¢(t)subscriptğ‘ğœ‰ğ‘¡ğ‘šsubscriptË™ğ‘¥ğœ‰ğ‘¡italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-m OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-x ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)p_{\xi}(t)=m\dot{x}_{\xi}(t), the kinetic energy K=p2/2â¢mğ¾superscriptğ‘22ğ‘šitalic-K RELOP:equals italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 italic-mK=p^{2}/2m satisfies

semantics.annotation: italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-m ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-x ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-Q OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)

br.p: with an additional â€˜quantum potentialâ€™ Qâ¢(x,t)ğ‘„ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-Q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)Q(x,t).

Particles in the ground state. For any Hamiltonian with a nondegenerate ground state Ïˆ0subscriptğœ“0italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\psi_{0} (satisfying Hâ¢Ïˆ0=E0â¢Ïˆ0ğ»subscriptğœ“0subscriptğ¸0subscriptğœ“0italic-H italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH\psi_{0}=E_{0}\psi_{0}), this ground state can always be taken to be real. Indeed, since the complex conjugate Ïˆ0*superscriptsubscriptğœ“0italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\psi_{0}^{*} also satisfies Hâ¢Ïˆ0*=E0â¢Ïˆ0*ğ»superscriptsubscriptğœ“0subscriptğ¸0superscriptsubscriptğœ“0italic-H italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endH\psi_{0}^{*}=E_{0}\psi_{0}^{*} and the ground state is nondegenerate, Ïˆ0*superscriptsubscriptğœ“0italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\psi_{0}^{*} must be a multiple of Ïˆ0subscriptğœ“0italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\psi_{0}, and scaling with the square root of the multiplier leaves a real eigenfunction.

div.p: The solution Ïˆğœ“italic-psi\psi of the SchrÃ¶dinger equation (5) corresponding to the ground state is

semantics.annotation: italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-i italic-t italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: If a particle can be in position xğ‘¥italic-xx at time tğ‘¡italic-tt then |Ïˆâ¢(x,t)|2>0superscriptğœ“ğ‘¥ğ‘¡20VERTBAR:| italic-psi OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0|\psi(x,t)|^{2}>0, hence Ïˆ0â‰ 0subscriptğœ“00italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0\psi_{0}\neq 0. A comparison with (12) therefore shows that particles in a nondegenerate ground state have a phase Sâ¢(x,t)=Â±tâ¢E0ğ‘†ğ‘¥ğ‘¡plus-or-minusğ‘¡subscriptğ¸0italic-S OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-t italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endS(x,t)=\pm tE_{0} independent of xğ‘¥italic-xx. Thus (11) implies that xâ¢(t)ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-x OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)x(t) is constant, xÎ¾â¢(t)=Î¾subscriptğ‘¥ğœ‰ğ‘¡ğœ‰italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-xix_{\xi}(t)=\xi for all tğ‘¡italic-tt. Thus each particle in the ensemble stands still.
This observation is puzzling and lead Einstein to reject the Bohmian interpretation; see Holland [20, Section 6.5.3] for a discussion and a defense.

br.p: The harmonic oscillator. A one-dimensional harmonic oscillator of mass mğ‘šitalic-mm, period Tğ‘‡italic-TT and angular frequency Ï‰=2â¢Ï€/Tğœ”2ğœ‹ğ‘‡italic-omega RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-T\omega=2\pi/T is described by the Hamiltonian

semantics.annotation: italic-H OPEN:( italic-p PUNCT:, italic-q CLOSE:) RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-m ARG:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-omega POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-m ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

br.p: The canonical commutation relations (2) imply that, for the Hamiltonian (20), the Heisenberg dynamics (3) of position and momentum are given by

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-d italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-d italic-t ARG:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-p OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-m ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-d italic-p OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-d italic-t ARG:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus italic-omega POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-m italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:,
\frac{dq(t)}{dt}=\frac{p(t)}{m},~{}~{}~{}\frac{dp(t)}{dt}=-\omega^{2}mq(t),

br.p: just as in the classical case. In particular, we can solve the dynamics explicitly in terms of the position operator qğ‘italic-qq and the momentum operator pğ‘italic-pp at time t=0ğ‘¡0italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:0t=0 as

semantics.annotation: italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-q TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-omega italic-t ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-p ARG:end ARG:start italic-omega italic-m ARG:end TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-omega italic-t PUNCT:,
q(t)=q\cos\omega t+\frac{p}{\omega m}\sin\omega t,
italic-p OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-p TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-omega italic-t ADDOP:minus italic-q italic-omega italic-m TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-omega italic-t PUNCT:,
p(t)=p\cos\omega t-q\omega m\sin\omega t,

br.p: again as in the classical case. In particular, qâ¢(t+T/2)=-qâ¢(t)ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘‡2ğ‘ğ‘¡italic-q OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-T MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)q(t+T/2)=-q(t), so that quantum mechanics predicts the time correlation

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-T MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus OPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0
\langle q(t+T/2)q(t)\rangle_{Q}=-\langle q(t)^{2}\rangle_{Q}<0

br.p: for an ensemble in an arbitrary pure (or even mixed) state. (âŸ¨qâ¢(t)2âŸ©Q=0subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡2ğ‘„0OPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\langle q(t)^{2}\rangle_{Q}=0 would be possible only in an eigenstate of qâ¢(t)ğ‘ğ‘¡italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)q(t) to the eigenvalue zero, but there is no such normalized state.)

div.p: On the other hand, interpreting the time correlations in a Bohmian sense, one finds from (19) and (13) that

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-T MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals INTOP:integral italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-T MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-xi CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-xi PERIOD:.
\langle q(t+T/2)q(t)\rangle_{B}=\int q_{\xi}(t+T/2)q_{\xi}(t)|\psi_{0}(\xi)|^{% 2}d\xi.

div.p: For particles in the ground state (which for the harmonic oscillator is nondegenerate), the discussion above shows that the right hand side is constant,

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-T MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0 PERIOD:.
\langle q(t+T/2)q(t)\rangle_{B}=\langle q(t)^{2}\rangle_{B}=\langle q(t)^{2}% \rangle_{Q}>0.

div.p: Comparing (21) and (22), we see that the quantum mechanical time correlation and the Bohmian time correlation have opposite signs.

br.p: Measuring time correlations. The fact that, in general, qâ¢(s)â¢qâ¢(t)ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘¡italic-q OPEN:( italic-s CLOSE:) italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)q(s)q(t) is not Hermitian and hence cannot be measured in individual events does not mean that the expectation on the left hand side of (21) is meaningless and has no relation to experiment. Indeed, one may define the expectation of an arbitrary quantity fğ‘“italic-ff in orthodox quantum mechanics (where all self-adjoint operators = observables can be measured, cf. Dirac [12, p.37]) in terms of the observables Ref=12â¢(f+f*)Reğ‘“12ğ‘“superscriptğ‘“BIGOP:Re italic-f RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OPEN:( italic-f ADDOP:plus italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\mathop{\rm Re}f=\frac{1}{2}(f+f^{*}) and Imf=12â¢iâ¢(f-f*)Imğ‘“12ğ‘–ğ‘“superscriptğ‘“BIGOP:Im italic-f RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-i ARG:end OPEN:( italic-f ADDOP:minus italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\mathop{\rm Im}f=\frac{1}{2i}(f-f^{*}) by

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle italic-f CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:assign OPEN:langle BIGOP:Re italic-f CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-i OPEN:langle BIGOP:Im italic-f CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.
\langle f\rangle_{Q}:=\langle\mathop{\rm Re}f\rangle_{Q}+i\langle\mathop{\rm Im% }f\rangle_{Q}.

br.p: This gives unambiguous values to all expectations, and is fully consistent with orthodox quantum mechanics. Of course, it may not be easy to measure RefReğ‘“BIGOP:Re italic-f\mathop{\rm Re}f and ImfImğ‘“BIGOP:Im italic-f\mathop{\rm Im}f, but an operational procedure for measuring arbitrary Hermitian functions of pğ‘italic-pp and qğ‘italic-qq by a suitable experimental arrangement can be found, e.g., in Lamb [22]. And quantum optics routinely deals with expectations and measurements of coherent states, which are eigenstates of nonhermitian annihilator operators; see, e.g. Leonhardt [23].

div.p: While the example of the harmonic oscillator is somewhat artificial, it has the advantage that all calculations can be done explicitly. Significant physical applications of time correlations are, however, made in statistical mechanics, where integrals over time correlations in thermodynamic equilibrium states are naturally linked to linear response functions, and hence are measurable as susceptibilities. See, e.g., Reichl [27, (15.161) and (15.172)]. Time correlations also arise in the calculation of optical spectra (Carmichael [8, Lecture 3.3]) and in the context of quantum Markov processes (Gardiner [16, Section 10.5]). Thus, at least in principle, it is possible to test the validity of the recipe (23) by experiment, by measuring susceptibilities or spectra directly, and by comparing the result to that obtained by applying (23) to measurements of RefReğ‘“BIGOP:Re italic-f\mathop{\rm Re}f and ImfImğ‘“BIGOP:Im italic-f\mathop{\rm Im}f.

As Arkadiusz Jadczyk (personal communication) pointed out, (23) implies that due to noncommutativity, the quantum mechanical time correlations âŸ¨qâ¢(s)â¢qâ¢(t)âŸ©Qsubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘„OPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-s CLOSE:) italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\langle q(s)q(t)\rangle_{Q} are complex in most states at most times, while time correlations computed from Bohm trajectories are always real. Thus an agreement would be a coincidence.
On the other hand, it is possible to avoid nonhermitian operators completely. Indeed, the contradiction persists in the following consequence of (21) and (22):

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-T MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) italic-q OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-T MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 OPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0 PUNCT:,
\langle q(t+T/2)q(t)+q(t)q(t+T/2)\rangle_{Q}=-2\langle q(t)^{2}\rangle_{Q}<0,

OPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-T MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) italic-q OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-T MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 OPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0 PERIOD:.
\langle q(t+T/2)q(t)+q(t)q(t+T/2)\rangle_{B}=2\langle q(t)^{2}\rangle_{Q}>0.

div.p: Note that qâ¢(t+T/2)â¢qâ¢(t)+qâ¢(t)â¢qâ¢(t+T/2)ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘‡2ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘‡2italic-q OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-T MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) italic-q OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-T MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)q(t+T/2)q(t)+q(t)q(t+T/2) is Hermitian, and (24) has the correct classical time correlation as limit when h-â†’0â†’superscriptâ„0italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to NUMBER:0h\hskip-5.690551pt^{-}\to 0. Symmetrized time correlations are discussed in the context of linear response theory in Kubo et al. [21, pp. 167-169].

br.p: In discussions with proponents of Bohmian mechanics, it is claimed that my interpretation of the Bohmian formalism is erroneous, in that I am not making the proper distinction between the ontological â€beableâ€ and the epistemological â€observableâ€, and compare the statistics of unobserved Bohm trajectories with those for quantum observations.

div.p: However, quantum mechanics can be used in practice without reference to the (still ill-defined) measurement mechanism, while Bohmian mechanics resorts to the latter to justify any discrepancy. This should not be the case if the â€˜beablesâ€™ were the real entities that Bohmian mechanics claims them to be. And indeed, the whole purpose of the local expectation values is to show the equivalence of expectations in Bohmian mechanics with those in quantum mechanics, without having to refer to measurement.

What else could the meaning of (18) be? The whole discussion in Holland [20, Section 3.5â€“3.8] becomes meaningless unless it is accepted that (18) is the real link between quantum mechanics and Bohmian mechanics, independent of any measurement questions. The probabilities â€“ Holland discusses these independent of expectations â€“ follow the rule (18) when Ağ´italic-AA is an orthogonal projector corresponding to the associated subspaces, and if the expectation rule fails then associated probabilities also fail.

Thus, one wonders why Bohmian mechanics, which can do calculations of single-time probabilities without reference to measurement questions, suddenly needs the measurement process to calculate probabilities of pair events occuring at two different times.

br.p: It may be noted that there are similar problems with multiple times in Nelsonâ€™s [25] stochastic quantum mechanics; Blanchard et al. [5] show how these problems can be overcome by a specific procedure for state reduction under measurement.

div.p: However, Bohmian mechanics does not seem to have such an option to rescue its interpretation since in the orthodox Bohmian interpretation, state reduction is a purely dynamical phenomenon. The suggestion to explain equivalence to quantummechanical predictions by invoking the measurement process leads at best to an approximate equivalence since Bohmian theory discusses measurement only in an approximate way (Holland [20, Chapter 8], Bohm & Hiley [7, Chapter 6]). And even then, specific efforts would be needed to show that the time correlations come out in the right way.

And the explanation by measurement fails completely if we consider the universe as a whole which, if supposed to behave deterministically according to the laws of Bohmian mechanics, has no meaningful way of defining time correlations apart from âŸ¨qâ¢(s)â¢qâ¢(t)âŸ©Bsubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘¡ğµOPEN:langle italic-q OPEN:( italic-s CLOSE:) italic-q OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\langle q(s)q(t)\rangle_{B}.

br.p: The ambiguity of local expectation values. To gain a better understanding of the problems of Bohmian mechanics from a slightly different point of view, we look more closely at the local expectation values that are supposed to define the real properties of particles, and that lie at the heart of the claim of Bohmian mechanics that all its predictions agree with those of quantum mechanics.

div.p: We first note that the recipe for calculating local expectation values is linear without restriction; in particular, for a particle in the ground state, where qÎ¾â¢(t)=Î¾subscriptğ‘ğœ‰ğ‘¡ğœ‰italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-xiq_{\xi}(t)=\xi and pÎ¾â¢(t)=0subscriptğ‘ğœ‰ğ‘¡0italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0p_{\xi}(t)=0, we have AÎ¾â¢(t)=Î±â¢Î¾subscriptğ´ğœ‰ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğœ‰italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-alpha italic-xiA_{\xi}(t)=\alpha\xi for any operator A=Î±â¢q+Î²â¢pğ´ğ›¼ğ‘ğ›½ğ‘italic-A RELOP:equals italic-alpha italic-q ADDOP:plus italic-beta italic-pA=\alpha q+\beta p. We use this to calculate the local expectation value of the Heisenberg position operator A=qâ¢(s)ğ´ğ‘ğ‘ italic-A RELOP:equals italic-q OPEN:( italic-s CLOSE:)A=q(s) at time sğ‘ italic-ss in the ground state of the harmonic oscillator, and find the remarkable formula

semantics.annotation: italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-xi TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-omega italic-s PERIOD:.
A_{\xi}(t)=\xi\cos\omega s.

div.p: Thus the objective value of A=qâ¢(s)ğ´ğ‘ğ‘ italic-A RELOP:equals italic-q OPEN:( italic-s CLOSE:)A=q(s) at any time tğ‘¡italic-tt is Î¾â¢cosâ¡Ï‰â¢sğœ‰ğœ”ğ‘ italic-xi TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-omega italic-s\xi\cos\omega s, corresponding to our intuition if we regard sğ‘ italic-ss as the physical time. It seems that, at least in the Bohmian picture of the harmonic oscillator, the Heisenberg time sğ‘ italic-ss is the real time while the SchrÃ¶dinger time tğ‘¡italic-tt only plays a formal and counterintuitive role.

This gives weight to what is called â€˜operator realismâ€™ in Daumer et al. [10], against the Bohmian program advocated there. And it makes the interpretation of local expectation values as real properties of the system highly dubious since these values depend on the choice of the Heisenberg time sğ‘ italic-ss.
In particular, for multi-time expectations, which are meaningful only in the Heisenberg picture, there is no distinguished single Heisenberg time, and hence no natural Bohmian interpretation.

Thus Bohmian mechanics can at best be said to reproduce a subset of quantum mechanics. It contradicts the quantum mechanical predictions about time correlations if one proceeds in the straightforward way that generalizes the basic formula (18) that accounts for agreement of single time expectations and single-time probabilities.

And Bohmian mechanics does not say anything at all about time correlations if the connection to quantum mechanics is kept more vague and left hidden behind a measurement process that is inherently approximate in Bohmian mechanics. Should this be the real link between quantum mechanics and Bohmian mechanics, one could claim the predictions of Bohmian mechanics to be approximately equal onlyto those of quantum mechanics, against the explicit assertions of many supporters of Bohmian mechanics.

In contrast to the claim by DÃ¼rr et al. [14], Bohmian mechanics does not account for all of the phenomena governed by nonrelativistic quantum mechanics. Indeed, it was shown that for a harmonic oscillator in the ground state, Bohmian mechanics and quantum mechanics predict values of opposite sign for certain time correlations. Bohmian mechanics therefore contradicts quantum mechanics at the level of time correlations. Since time correlations can be observed experimentally via linear response theory, Bohmian mechanics and quantum mechanics cannot both describe experimental reality.

Due to the complicated form of the Bohmian dynamics, it seems difficult to compute time correlations for realistic scenarios where a comparison with linear response theory and hence with experiment would become possible. But perhaps numerical simulations are feasible. On the other hand, it is unlikely that, if the predictions of quantum mechanics and Bohmian mechanics differ in such a simple case, they would agree in more realistic situations.

The time correlations used in statistical mechanics are those from quantum mechanics and not those from Bohm trajectories. Moreover, they can be calculated and used without reference to any theory about the measurement process. If an elaborate theory of quantum observation is needed to reinterpret Bohmian mechanics â€“ so that it matches quantum mechanics and thus restores the connection to statistical mechanics â€“ then Bohmian mechanics is at best approximately equivalent to quantum mechanics and, I believe, irrelevant to practice.
It is therefore likely that Bohmian mechanics is ruled out as a possible foundation of physics.
